greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle formed as follows: For n-th row, n >= 0, record the A000041(n) partitions of n; for each partition, write down number of ways to arrange the parts.
link: M. Abramowitz and I. A. Stegun, eds., Handbook of Mathematical Functions, National Bureau of Standards, Applied Math. Series 55, Tenth Printing, 1972 [alternative scanned copy].
example: This is a function of the individual partitions of an integer. For n = 0 to 5 the terms are (1), (1), (2,1), (6,2,1), (24,6,4,2,1). The partitions are ordered with the largest part sizes first, so the row 4 indices are [4], [3,1], [2,2], [2,1,1] and [1,1,1,1].
mathematica: Table[Map[Function[n, Apply[Times, n! ]], IntegerPartitions[i]], {i,0,8}] // Flatten (* _Geoffrey Critzer_, May 19 2009 *)
program: return [product(factorial(part) for part in partition) for partition in Partitions(n)]
for n in (0..6): print(A069123row(n)) # _Peter Luschny_, Apr 10 2020
xref: Using Abramowitz-Stegun ordering of partitions this becomes array A134133.
results.author: _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Apr 07 2002
